contexts.walking: Similar to average walking speed (4-6.5 km/h)
contexts.running: Similar to jogging or running speed (9-20 km/h)
contexts.cycling: Similar to casual cycling speed (15-30 km/h)
contexts.cityDriving: Similar to city driving speed (30-50 km/h)
contexts.highwayDriving: Similar to highway driving speed (90-130 km/h)
contexts.lightWind: Similar to light breeze wind speed (Beaufort 1-3)
contexts.commercialAircraft: Similar to commercial aircraft cruising speed (800-1000 km/h)
contexts.speedOfSound: Near the speed of sound at sea level (~1,234 km/h)

disclaimer.text: This converter provides accurate mathematical conversions between standard speed units. Results are rounded for display purposes.
disclaimer.note: Speed conversions are based on internationally standardized unit definitions. For scientific or engineering applications requiring extreme precision, consult official metrology resources.

seo.whatIsContent: A speed converter is a tool that transforms speed measurements from one unit to another. Whether you need to convert kilometers per hour to miles per hour for a road trip abroad, understand wind speeds in knots for sailing, or convert meters per second for scientific calculations, this converter handles all common speed units instantly. Speed (or velocity) measures how fast an object moves relative to a reference point, expressed as distance traveled per unit of time.
seo.unitKmh: Kilometers per hour (km/h) - The standard speed unit in most countries, used for road traffic, weather reports, and general purposes in metric system countries.
seo.unitMph: Miles per hour (mph) - The primary speed unit in the United States, United Kingdom, and a few other countries, commonly used for vehicle speedometers and speed limits.
seo.unitMs: Meters per second (m/s) - The SI base unit for speed, used in scientific contexts, physics calculations, and international standards.
seo.unitFts: Feet per second (ft/s) - Used primarily in American engineering, ballistics, and some specialized applications.
seo.unitKnots: Knots (kn) - A nautical unit equal to one nautical mile per hour, used universally in aviation and maritime navigation.
seo.useCase1: International travel - Convert speed limits when driving in countries using different units (US to Europe, UK to EU)
seo.useCase2: Aviation and sailing - Convert between knots and km/h or mph for flight planning and navigation
seo.useCase3: Sports and fitness - Compare running, cycling, or swimming speeds across different measurement systems
seo.useCase4: Weather interpretation - Understand wind speed forecasts given in unfamiliar units
seo.useCase5: Scientific and engineering work - Convert between m/s and practical units for calculations and reports
seo.howToUseTitle: How to Use This Speed Converter
seo.howToUseStep1: Enter the speed value you want to convert in the input field
seo.howToUseStep2: Select the source unit (the unit you're converting from) using the 'From' dropdown
seo.howToUseStep3: Select the target unit (the unit you're converting to) using the 'To' dropdown
seo.howToUseStep4: View the converted result instantly - the conversion happens in real-time as you type
seo.howToUseStep5: Use the 'Swap Units' button to quickly reverse the conversion direction
seo.tip1: For a quick km/h to mph estimate, divide by 1.6 (or multiply mph by 1.6 for km/h)
seo.tip2: Knots are approximately 1.15 mph or 1.85 km/h - useful for quick mental calculations
seo.tip3: 1 m/s equals 3.6 km/h exactly - a handy conversion factor to remember
seo.tip4: The speed of sound at sea level is approximately 343 m/s, 1,234 km/h, or 767 mph
seo.tip5: When comparing athletic speeds, remember that elite marathon runners average about 20 km/h (12.4 mph)
seo.faq1Question: How do I convert km/h to mph?
seo.faq1Answer: To convert kilometers per hour to miles per hour, divide the km/h value by 1.60934. For example, 100 km/h equals approximately 62.14 mph. Our converter does this calculation automatically and shows the precise result.
seo.faq2Question: What is the difference between speed and velocity?
seo.faq2Answer: In everyday use, speed and velocity are often used interchangeably. Technically, speed is a scalar quantity (just magnitude), while velocity is a vector (magnitude plus direction). For unit conversions, they're treated the same way since we're only dealing with the magnitude.
seo.faq3Question: Why do ships and aircraft use knots?
seo.faq3Answer: Knots are based on nautical miles, which are directly related to the Earth's geometry (one nautical mile equals one minute of latitude). This makes navigation calculations simpler, as distances on nautical charts correspond directly to latitude readings. One knot equals one nautical mile per hour.
seo.faq4Question: What is the most accurate speed unit?
seo.faq4Answer: Meters per second (m/s) is the SI base unit for speed and is used in scientific contexts for its precision and universality. However, 'accuracy' depends on context - all units can express speed with equal precision; they're just different scales for measuring the same phenomenon.
seo.faq5Answer: Mach 1 is the speed of sound, which varies with temperature and altitude. At sea level and 20 degrees Celsius, Mach 1 is approximately 343 m/s, 1,234 km/h, or 767 mph. The Mach number is not a fixed speed unit but a ratio of speed to the local speed of sound.
seo.faq6Question: What speed unit do European countries use?
seo.faq6Answer: Most European countries use kilometers per hour (km/h) for road speeds and daily use. The UK is an exception, using miles per hour (mph) for road traffic. For scientific work, meters per second (m/s) is the international standard.
seo.faq7Question: How do I convert wind speed from knots to km/h?
seo.faq7Answer: To convert knots to km/h, multiply by 1.852. For example, 20 knots equals 37.04 km/h. This is useful when interpreting marine weather forecasts or aviation weather reports, which typically use knots.
seo.faq8Answer: Most conversion factors used here are exact or defined values. For example, 1 mile is exactly 1.609344 kilometers, and 1 nautical mile is exactly 1.852 kilometers. The m/s is the SI base unit, so other conversions are derived from these defined relationships.
